Mr. Stevens.
MR. STEVENS: Thank you.
In introducing the paper entitled "Governance: The
World Bank's Experience", I would just like to make four
brief points.
The first is that the present report is not an
exercise in further defining what the Bank means by
governance. That was done two years ago by the first report
to the Board on governance and by the General Counsel, Mr.
Shihata, in his legal memorandum of 1991.
If the definitions are repeated in this report, it
is simply to provide the context in which the findings are
presented. The report's purpose is descriptive to set forth
what the Bank has been doing in the area of governance for
the past two years. It is an exercise in stocktaking, not in
the sense of a mechanical listing of everything that is being
done, but a description of the main areas and the type of
MILLER REPORTING CO., INC. ~07 C Street. N,E. Washington, D.C, 20002  nm 5
work being done illustrated by a broad range of lending
operations, ESW and research examples.
The second point to emphasize is that, compared
with a few years back, a considerable amount of work is being
done on governance in the Bank. The nature of governance
makes it hard to measure the exact volume of the work, but it
is clear that it has become extensive in many countries and
in all regions, in lending operations, in economic and sector
work and in research.
Some of this work is substantially or entirely new
areas for the Bank. Examples are assisting governments with
legal system reform, participatory approaches to the design
and implementation of projects, and strengthening the
fundamental accountability mechanisms of governments.
Much of the work is in mainstream areas of
governance, such as public sector management, which has long
been a concern of the Bank, but within these traditional
areas the language changes, methodology is evolving and new
approaches are being tried.
The third point I would like to make is that all of
this is taking place within the mandate of the Bank's
Articles. As the report makes clear, the Bank's concern with
government is exclusively with the contribution it makes to
MILLER REPORTING CO., INC. ~07 C Street, RE. Washington, D.C. 20002  run 6
social and economic development and not with the form of
political regime.
There are certainly aspects of governance such as
military expenditure and the role the Bank is required to
playas Chair of the Consultative Group process, which
requires sensitive and careful handling in order not to
overstep the boundaries of that mandate.
Overall, the economic and social domains of
governance have proved to be very broad in practice. This
has provided considerable scope for staff, particularly so
when goverrunents have actively sought the assistance of the
Bank in analyzing governance issues, bringing to bear the
experience of other countries and helping them with the
design and implementation of reforms.
The final point I would like to make is a personal
observation, the effect of governance work on Bank staff.
While it is true that some staff still feel uncomfortable
with the governance dimension, many others have seen it as an
opportunity for meaningful work. In turn, this has deepened
their understanding of how goverrunents work, the proper role
of the public sector, how it can be made more accountable,
and how institutional strengthening can be fostered to the
benefit of sustainable development.
